Teaching

APEC 1201: Applications of Excel in Economics and Management
Fall 2024-Present
The course introduces the fundamental functions and features of Microsoft Excel, emphasizing data visualization and presentation skills. Students learn best practices for visually communicating data—creating clear, engaging tables and graphs—along with more advanced Excel tools such as optimization, regression, and macros.

title: Hayk Mardanyan
text:
Abstract

The Republic of Armenia’s economic and financial sectors are heavily reliant on foreign countries, particularly the Russian Federation. This reliance spans critical areas, including energy, agriculture, trade, transportation, foreign direct investment (FDI), and remittances. This report evaluates the risks associated with Armenia’s dependence on a narrow set of external partners and underscores the need for economic diversification. Key highlights are that the majority of Armenia’s natural gas and petroleum imports originate from Russia, while its agricultural trade, machinery imports, and textile exports also exhibit significant concentration. Additionally, Russian entities dominate strategic infrastructure such as telecommunications and rail transport, as well as electricity generation, transmission and distribution. Remittances from Russia have constituted an average of 60% of total remittance inflows in 2013-2022, further exposing Armenia to external economic shocks. Such dependence threatens Armenia’s economic sovereignty, heightening vulnerability to foreign economic leverage and periods of economic instability abroad. To mitigate these risks, the report advocates for diversification of trade partnerships, investments, and domestic production, aiming to bolster resilience, encourage innovation, and foster sustainable economic growth.

title: Hayk Mardanyan
text:
Applied Economist • PhD Student at the University of Minnesota
Minneapolis, MN, USA



Hayk Mardanyan is a PhD student in Applied Economics at the University of Minnesota. Prior to this, he has received a Bachelor of Science degree in Economics and Mathematics from the University of Minnesota, and a Master of Science degree in Applied Economics from the University of Minnesota. Hayk Mardanyan has worked closely with the Minnesota Department of Commerce, collaborating with state economists on projects ranging from the evaluation of investor-owned utilities’ energy efficiency programs, the role of weather derivatives in wholesale electricity markets, and the impact of tariffs on retail electricity prices. Hayk Mardanyan has also interned at the Central Bank of the Republic of Armenia, advising the Bank on areas of diversification for the economy in order to reduce economic reliance on foreign sources and diversify its energy portfolio. Hayk’s current research interests include energy economics and applied econometrics.

The Effect of the Demand-Side Management Financial Incentive Program on Energy Savings: Evidence from Minnesota


Abstract

In Minnesota, the Public Utilities Commission (PUC) allocates annual financial incentives to investor-owned electric and gas utilities through the Demand-Side Management (DSM) Financial Incentive Program, rewarding utilities for achieving energy savings thresholds. The program is designed to offset energy companies’ disincentive to save energy due to the resulting loss in energy sales volume and revenues. While utilities consistently advocate for increased financial incentives, critics argue the awards are excessive and call for program scaling. This paper estimates the causal effect of an additional dollar in financial incentives on energy savings (kWh), using lagged average winter temperatures as an instrument. We find that each additional incentive dollar generates a first-year energy savings increase of 5.34 kWh, corresponding to a 53.5-cent first-year return and an average present discounted lifetime return of $6.65 per dollar spent, indicating that investments in the DSM Financial Incentive Program are financially justified. These results imply a present discounted value of $327.05 in lifetime savings for the average residential ratepayer in Minnesota. The study situates these findings within the broader context of net benefits accrued to Minnesota residents from energy efficiency programs administered by the state’s investor-owned electric and gas utilities.
